data.title: Blair House
data.text:
The President’s Guest House

AN ELEGANT SETTING REFLECTING OUR COUNTRY’S HISTORY

Furnished with fine antique furniture, objects, and art, Blair House is carefully curated to portray the history, values, and hospitality of the nation. The home is maintained by the U.S. Department of State and the General Services Administration. Interior décor, furnishings, and heritage collections are supported through financial and in-kind contributions to the Blair House Foundation.

A storied political history

Built as a private home in 1824, Blair House has played an important role in nearly 190 years of American political, diplomatic and cultural history—from Andrew Jackson’s “Kitchen Cabinet,” to private chats with Abraham Lincoln, to Harry S. Truman’s crucial leadership as World War II ended and the Cold War began. Now, as then, U.S. Presidents continue to rely on Blair House as a significant foreign policy tool.

Diplomacy In Action

Located across from the White House on Pennsylvania Avenue, Blair House has served as the President’s Guest House since its purchase by the U.S. government during World War II. Under the stewardship of the Department of State, it welcomes visiting heads of state, ambassadors, and other notables in gracious, secure surroundings in the heart of the nation’s capital.

VIEW OUR OFFICIAL GUEST BOOK

About the Blair House Foundation

Founded in 1985, the Blair House Foundation is a charitable, tax-exempt, non-partisan organization committed to raising private funds from across the nation to create and maintain the beautiful rooms, gardens, and amenities of Blair House.

Government funding supports the staffing and structural needs of Blair House, but it is the Foundation’s responsibility to preserve and refresh the furnishings, décor, fine arts, and gardens. Through the generosity of American individuals, foundations, and corporations, the Foundation is able to ensure Blair House remains a beautiful and welcoming home away from home for world leaders.
